reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same one you learned with the kanji, probably because it's attached to things usually, so it's treated like on'yomi.
You learned this reading already when you learned 房!

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:

Do you know a <vocabulary>Lord</vocabulary>? Imagine it being someone named <vocabulary>Mr.</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Ms.</vocabulary> <reading>Don</reading> (どの). If you know a Don, that's great, imagine that person. If you don't, think of a famous Don that's out there.

Everything except the 生 uses the readings you learned with the kanji, and you learned this reading of 生 when you learned 一生. You've really been going <vocabulary>all out</vocabulary> to learn these readings!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meanings.meaning: To Go Out Into The World
To Be Released To The Public

reading_mnemonic: This uses kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you should already know by now, so I think you're good to go!

So this <vocabulary>enchanting</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>charming</vocabulary> feeling is <vocabulary>mysterious</vocabulary>... some would say 怪しい (suspicious). It actually shares the same reading as 怪しい. They're kind of similar, too. Here's the difference:

怪しい usually has a negative feel to it whereas 妖しい generally has a positive feel. 妖しい also feels more mysterious or has a magical edge.

Whenever you're really <vocabulary>glad</vocabulary> to be alive, you look up at the sun's rays and sing, "<reading>Ooh, ray</reading>s (うれ), I'm so glad you're here!" Then your Uncle Ray comes dancing into the room and sings back, "Ooh, Ray is <vocabulary>happy</vocabulary> you're happy!" The sun's rays and Uncle Ray both make you really happy.

What is multiplying? Your use of the word "<reading>fu</reading>" (ふ) for when you laugh. You used to say just "ha ha ha" like everyone else. Now the occurrences of you saying <reading>fufufu</reading> is really multiplying. You might also notice that this is similar to the word 増える, which means "to increase." This has a similar meaning and the same reading, use that to your advantage!

This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 殿 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Feudal Lord</vocabulary>s were pretty brutal back in the day. If you did something wrong he'd get to punish you. What kind of punishment? Well, he'd cut off your toe! That left most people yelling, "My <reading>toe?! NO</reading>!" (との). Imagine screaming "Toe no!" over and over as the feudal lord got closer and closer. Holding a pair of hedge clippers or something. Maybe if you yell "toe no" enough times, he'll change his mind.
The reading comes from 沖縄 and 県 put together.

For the reading, think about another word that is similar: 帰る. With 帰る you are returning to somewhere. With this word, you're returning to look back on something. They share the same first part reading, so you should take advantage of that. 帰る → かえり.
